Includes the ignore deprecated @ConfigItem patch written by @machi1990 .

commit.message:
feat(docs): do not include deprecated config items in the generated config doc

Fixes https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues/7746

nodes.bodyText: It would be nice to add a [source, properties] for this case. For example, how do I connect to a DB2 DB?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -9,55 +9,120 @@ include::./attributes.adoc[]
 
 Many projects that use data require connections to a relational database.
 
-The main way of obtaining connections to a database is to use a datasource and configure a JDBC driver.
+The usual way of obtaining connections to a database is to use a datasource and configure a JDBC driver.
+But you might also prefer using a reactive driver to connect to your database in a reactive way.
 
-In Quarkus, the preferred datasource and connection pooling implementation is https://agroal.github.io/[Agroal].
+Quarkus gets you covered for both:
 
+* For JDBC, the preferred datasource and connection pooling implementation is https://agroal.github.io/[Agroal].
+* For reactive, we use the https://vertx.io/[Vert.x] reactive drivers.
+
+Both are configured via a unified and flexible configuration.
+
+[NOTE]
+====
 Agroal is a modern, light weight connection pool implementation designed for very high performance and scalability,
 and features first class integration with the other components in Quarkus, such as security, transaction management components, health metrics.
+====
 
 This guide will explain how to:
 
 * configure a datasource, or multiple datasources
 * how to obtain a reference to those datasources in code
 * which pool tuning configuration properties are available
 
-== Prerequisites
+This guide is mainly about datasource configuration.
+If you want more details about how to consume and make use of a reactive datasource,
+refer to the link:reactive-sql-clients[Reactive SQL clients guide].
+
+== TL;DR
 
-To complete this guide, you will need:
+This is a quick introduction to datasource configuration.
+If you want a better understanding of how all this works, this guide has a lot more information in the subsequent paragraphs.
 
-* less than 10 minutes
-* an IDE
-* JDK 1.8+ installed with `JAVA_HOME` configured appropriately
-* Apache Maven 3.5.3+
+=== JDBC datasource
 
-== Creating the Maven project
+Add the `agroal` extension plus one of `jdbc-derby`, `jdbc-h2`, `jdbc-mariadb`, `jdbc-mssql`, `jdbc-mysql` or `jdbc-postgresql`.
 
-First, we need a new project. Create a new project with the following command:
+Then configure your datasource:
 
-[source,shell,subs=attributes+]
+[source, properties]
 ----
-mvn io.quarkus:quarkus-maven-plugin:{quarkus-version}:create \
-    -DprojectGroupId=org.acme \
-    -DprojectArtifactId=agroal-quickstart \
-    -DclassName="org.acme.datasource.GreetingResource" \
-    -Dpath="/hello"
-cd agroal-quickstart
+quarkus.datasource.db-kind=postgresql
+quarkus.datasource.username=<your username>
+quarkus.datasource.password=<your password>
+
+quarkus.datasource.jdbc.url=jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/hibernate_orm_test
+quarkus.datasource.jdbc.min-size=4
+quarkus.datasource.jdbc.max-size=16
 ----
 
-This will generate:
+=== Reactive datasource
+
+Add either the `reactive-pg-client` or the `reactive-mysql-client` extension.
+
+Then configure your reactive datasource:
+
+[source, properties]
+----
+quarkus.datasource.db-kind=postgresql
+quarkus.datasource.username=<your username>
+quarkus.datasource.password=<your password>
+
+quarkus.datasource.reactive.url=postgresql:///your_database
+quarkus.datasource.reactive.max-size=20
+----
 
-* the Maven structure
-* a landing page accessible on `http://localhost:8080`
-* an example `Dockerfile` files for both `native` and `jvm` modes
-* the application configuration file
-* an `org.acme.datasource.GreetingResource` resource
-* an example integration test
+== Default datasource
 
-== Adding maven dependencies
+A datasource can be either a JDBC datasource, a reactive one or both.
+It all depends on how you configure it and which extensions you added to your project.
 
-Next, you will need to add the `quarkus-agroal` dependency to your project.
+To define a datasource, start with the following:
+
+[source, properties]
+----
+quarkus.datasource.db-kind=h2
+----
+
+The database kind defines which type of database you will connect to.
+
+We currently include these built-in database kinds:
+
+* Derby: `derby`
+* H2: `h2`
+* MariaDB: `mariadb`
+* Microsoft SQL Server: `mssql`
+* MySQL: `mysql`
+* PostgreSQL: `postgresql`, `pgsql` or `pg`
+
+Note that these database kinds only facilitate things.
+For instance, when we have a JDBC driver extension for a given kind,
+we resolve the JDBC driver to use automatically so you don't need to configure it yourself.
+If you want to use a database kind outside of this list, just use `other` or whatever name you prefer.

+quarkus.datasource.jdbc.url=jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/hibernate_orm_test
+----
 
-A viable configuration file would be:
+[NOTE]
+====
+Note the `jdbc` prefix in the property name.
+All the configuration properties specific to JDBC have this prefix.
+====
 
-[source,properties]
---
-quarkus.datasource.url=jdbc:h2:tcp://localhost/mem:default
-quarkus.datasource.driver=org.h2.Driver
-quarkus.datasource.username=username-default
-quarkus.datasource.min-size=3
-quarkus.datasource.max-size=13
---
+[TIP]
+====
+For more information about the JDBC URL format, please refer to the <<jdbc-url,JDBC url reference section>>.
+====
 
-There are other configuration options, detailed below.
+When using one of the built-in datasource kinds, the JDBC driver is resolved automatically to the following values:

-For more information about the Agroal extension configuration please refer to the <<configuration-reference, Configuration Reference>>.
+.Database kind to JDBC driver mapping
+|===
+|Database kind |JDBC driver |XA driver
 
-=== JDBC URL configurations
+|`derby`
+|`org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDriver`
+|`org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientXADataSource`
 
-Each of the supported databases contains different JDBC URL configuration options.
-Going into each of those options is beyond the scope of this document, but it gives an overview of each database URL and link to the official documentation.
+|`h2`
+|`org.h2.Driver`
+|`org.h2.jdbcx.JdbcDataSource`
 
-==== H2
+|`mariadb`
+|`org.mariadb.jdbc.Driver`
+|`org.mariadb.jdbc.MySQLDataSource`
 
-`jdbc:h2:{ {.|mem:}[name] | [file:]fileName | {tcp|ssl}:[//]server[:port][,server2[:port]]/name }[;key=value...]`
+|`mssql`
+|`com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver`
+|`com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerXADataSource`
 
-Example:: `jdbc:h2:tcp://localhost/~/test`, `jdbc:h2:mem:myDB`
+|`mysql`
+|`com.mysql.cj.jdbc.Driver`
+|`com.mysql.cj.jdbc.MysqlXADataSource`
 
-H2 is an embedded database.
-It can run as a server, based on a file, or live completely in memory.
-All of these options are available as listed above.

+So it is not currently possible to create multiple reactive datasources.
+
+[NOTE]
+====
+At the moment, Hibernate ORM supports only one persistence unit which uses the default datasource.
